Signals

Signals are the foundation of PhilJS's fine-grained reactivity system. They're simple, powerful primitives for managing state.

What Are Signals?

A signal is a reactive primitive that holds a value and notifies subscribers when that value changes. Unlike React's useState, signals don't cause component re-renders. Instead, they update only the specific DOM nodes that depend on them.

1import { createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
4 
5// Read the value
6console.log(count()); // 0
7 
8// Update the value
9setCount(1);
10console.log(count()); // 1
11 
12// Update based on previous value
13setCount(prev => prev + 1);
14console.log(count()); // 2
i

Getter Functions

Signals return a getter function. Always call count() to read the value, not just count.

Creating Signals

1// Simple value
2const [name, setName] = createSignal('Alice');
3 
4// Object
5const [user, setUser] = createSignal({
6  id: 1,
7  name: 'Alice',
8  email: 'alice@example.com'
9});
10 
11// Array
12const [items, setItems] = createSignal<string[]>([]);
13 
14// With type annotation
15const [count, setCount] = createSignal<number>(0);
16 
17// Optional initial value (undefined by default)
18const [value, setValue] = createSignal<string>();
19console.log(value()); // undefined

Updating Signals

Direct Updates

1const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
2 
3// Set a new value
4setCount(10);
5 
6// Update based on previous value
7setCount(prev => prev + 1);

Object Updates

1const [user, setUser] = createSignal({
2  name: 'Alice',
3  age: 30
4});
5 
6// Replace entire object
7setUser({ name: 'Bob', age: 25 });
8 
9// Update specific properties (spread pattern)
10setUser(prev => ({ ...prev, age: 31 }));
11 
12// Multiple updates
13setUser(prev => ({
14  ...prev,
15  age: prev.age + 1,
16  lastUpdated: Date.now()
17}));

Array Updates

1const [items, setItems] = createSignal<string[]>([]);
2 
3// Add item
4setItems(prev => [...prev, 'new item']);
5 
6// Remove item
7setItems(prev => prev.filter(item => item !== 'removed'));
8 
9// Update item
10setItems(prev => prev.map(item =>
11  item === 'old' ? 'new' : item
12));
13 
14// Clear array
15setItems([]);

Reading Signals

!

Common Mistake

Always call the getter function to read signal values. Reading count instead of count() won't track the dependency in effects!
1const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
2 
3// Correct: Read value
4const value = count();
5 
6// Wrong: This just references the getter function
7const wrong = count; // typeof wrong === 'function'
8 
9// In JSX
10function Counter() {
11  const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
12 
13  return (
14    <div>
15      {/* Correct: */}
16      <p>Count: {count()}</p>
17 
18      {/* Wrong - will display [Function] */}
19      <p>Count: {count}</p>
20    </div>
21  );
22}

How Reactivity Works

Signals automatically track where they're being read and update only those locations:

1import { createSignal, createEffect } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
4 
5// This effect automatically subscribes to count
6createEffect(() => {
7  console.log('Count changed:', count());
8});
9 
10// Logs: "Count changed: 0"
11 
12setCount(1);
13// Logs: "Count changed: 1"
14 
15setCount(2);
16// Logs: "Count changed: 2"

Derived Values with Memos

Create computed signals that automatically update when dependencies change:

1import { createSignal, createMemo } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [firstName, setFirstName] = createSignal('John');
4const [lastName, setLastName] = createSignal('Doe');
5 
6// Memo automatically tracks dependencies
7const fullName = createMemo(() => {
8  return `${firstName()} ${lastName()}`;
9});
10 
11console.log(fullName()); // "John Doe"
12 
13setFirstName('Jane');
14console.log(fullName()); // "Jane Doe"
i

Memos are Cached

Memos only recalculate when their dependencies change. Multiple reads return the cached value.

Batch Updates

Batch multiple signal updates to prevent unnecessary re-computations:

1import { createSignal, batch, createEffect } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [firstName, setFirstName] = createSignal('John');
4const [lastName, setLastName] = createSignal('Doe');
5 
6createEffect(() => {
7  console.log(`Name: ${firstName()} ${lastName()}`);
8});
9 
10// Without batching: effect runs twice
11setFirstName('Jane');
12setLastName('Smith');
13// Logs:
14// "Name: Jane Doe"
15// "Name: Jane Smith"
16 
17// With batching: effect runs once
18batch(() => {
19  setFirstName('Alice');
20  setLastName('Johnson');
21});
22// Logs only:
23// "Name: Alice Johnson"

Untracked Reads

Sometimes you need to read a signal without creating a dependency:

1import { createSignal, createEffect, untrack } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3const [count, setCount] = createSignal(0);
4const [name, setName] = createSignal('Alice');
5 
6createEffect(() => {
7  console.log('Count:', count());
8 
9  // Read name without subscribing to it
10  const currentName = untrack(name);
11  console.log('Name (untracked):', currentName);
12});
13 
14setCount(1);
15// Logs:
16// "Count: 1"
17// "Name (untracked): Alice"
18 
19setName('Bob');
20// Nothing logged - effect doesn't subscribe to name

Signal Options

1import { createSignal } from 'philjs-core';
2 
3// Custom equality function
4const [value, setValue] = createSignal(
5  { x: 0, y: 0 },
6  {
7    equals: (a, b) => a.x === b.x && a.y === b.y
8  }
9);
10 
11// This won't trigger updates (same values)
12setValue({ x: 0, y: 0 });
13 
14// This will trigger updates (different values)
15setValue({ x: 1, y: 1 });

Advanced Patterns

Signal Factories

1function createToggle(initial = false) {
2  const [value, setValue] = createSignal(initial);
3 
4  return {
5    value,
6    toggle: () => setValue(v => !v),
7    setTrue: () => setValue(true),
8    setFalse: () => setValue(false),
9  };
10}
11 
12// Usage
13const darkMode = createToggle(false);
14 
15darkMode.toggle();
16console.log(darkMode.value()); // true
17 
18darkMode.setFalse();
19console.log(darkMode.value()); // false

Signal Arrays

1function createSignalArray<T>(initial: T[] = []) {
2  const [items, setItems] = createSignal<T[]>(initial);
3 
4  return {
5    items,
6    push: (item: T) => setItems(prev => [...prev, item]),
7    pop: () => setItems(prev => prev.slice(0, -1)),
8    remove: (index: number) =>
9      setItems(prev => prev.filter((_, i) => i !== index)),
10    update: (index: number, value: T) =>
11      setItems(prev => prev.map((item, i) => i === index ? value : item)),
12    clear: () => setItems([]),
13  };
14}
15 
16// Usage
17const todos = createSignalArray<string>();
18todos.push('Learn PhilJS');
19todos.push('Build app');
20console.log(todos.items()); // ['Learn PhilJS', 'Build app']

Performance Considerations

  • Fine-grained updates: Only affected DOM nodes update, not entire components
  • No virtual DOM: Direct DOM updates eliminate diffing overhead
  • Automatic tracking: No manual dependency arrays to maintain
  • Lazy evaluation: Memos only compute when accessed
  • Structural sharing: Updates don't require deep cloning

Best Practices

  1. Keep signals simple: Store primitive values when possible
  2. Use memos for derived state: Don't duplicate state
  3. Batch related updates: Use batch() for multiple changes
  4. Avoid conditionally reading signals: Always read at the top level of effects
  5. Use stores for complex state: See Stores for nested reactivity
